wikipedia_page.main: Richard Harding (1770 - 13 November 1805) was a British forger.  He was capitally indicted and convicted of the forgery of brass duty legal stamps placed on the Ace of Spades and the selling and uttering of playing cards with the same, while knowing such duty stamp to be false.  He was hanged at Old Bailey, London, England in 1805.

link_mentions.page: Capital punishment in the United Kingdom
response: *13 November 1805: Richard Harding was hanged for uttering playing cards with a forged ace of spades.

One maker of cards was caught in possession of forged aces and the equipment to produce them. This was a capital offence, the prosecutor the Attorney General Spencer Perceval (later to become the Prime Minister assassinated in 1812) obtained the conviction of Richard Harding and he was hanged in 1805. The association of the ace of spades with death may spring from such events.
